1. What are the two roles of the Transport Layer? **(4) (S3)**
  - Logical communications between applications running on different hosts
  - The link between the application layer and the lower layers
2. What are the five responsibilities of the Transport layer? **(6) (S4)**
  - Tracking individual conversations
  - Segmenting data and reassembling segments
  - Adding header information
  - Identifying the applications
  - Conversation multiplexing
3. What is the purpose of conversation MULTIPLEXING? **(2) (S4)**
  - To interleave multiple conversations on the same network
4. What are the five TCP basic operations to provide reliability and flow control? **(5) (S6)**
  - Number and track data segments
  - Sequence data
  - Acknowledge received data
  - Retransmit any unacknowledged data
  - Send data at an efficient rate
5. Why is TCP a connection-oriented protocol? **(2) (S6)**
  - Because it must establish a connection between the sender and the receiver
6. Why is UDP known as a best-effort protocol? **(2) (S7)**
  - Because it does not provide reliability and flow control
7. Why is UDP a connectionless protocol? **(2) (S7)**
  - Because it does not require an established connection
8. Why is UDP a stateless protocol? **(2) (S7)**
  - Because it does not track information sent or received
9. Which layer 4 protocol is good for voice and DNS? **(2) (S8, 15)**
  - UDP
10. Why is TCP a stateful protocol? **(2) (S10)**
  - Because it keeps track of the state of the communication session
11. What information in the transport layer header identifies the application? **(2) (S10, 14)**
  - Source and destination port numbers
12. Give four examples of applications that use TCP. **(4) (S12)**
  - HTTP
  - FTP
  - SMTP
  - SSH
13. Give six examples of applications that use UCP. **(4) (S15)**
  - DHCP
  - DNS
  - SMMP
  - TFTP
  - VoIP
  - Video Conferencing
14. Define the SOCKET and the socket pair. **(4) (S17)**
  - Socket: IP address + port number
  - Socket pair: Source socket + destination socket

16. What are the three types of the port number groups? **(8) (S18)**
  - Registered ports
  - Well-known Ports
  - Dynamic or Private ports
17. A message originates on PC1 and is destined for the **web** server. Fill in the following information. **(4) (S18, 19)**  
  - Source IP **192.168.1.10**  
  - Destination IP **192.168.0.254**  
  - Source Port **Random Number**  
  - Destination Port **80**
18. Can ONE server have two or more services assigned to the same port number? Why? **(4) (20)**
  - No, because there is no way to differentiate between services
19. Explain the steps of the TCP connection establishment. **(6) (S21)**
  - Step 1: Client A requests a client-to-server session with the server
  - Step 2: Server B acknowledges the client-to-server request and requests a server-to-client communication session
  - Step 3: Client A acknowledges the server-to-client communication session
20. How is the ordered delivery of segments achieved? **(4) (23)**
  - By assigning sequence numbers in the header of each segment
21. What is the purpose of flow control? **(4) (25)**
  - Adjusts the rate of data flow between source and destination
22. What information in the segment header is used by the flow control? **(4) (25)**
  - Number of bytes
  - Acknowledgment
23. Explain the window size concept. **(4) (25)**
  - Number of bytes that:
    - The destination device can accept and process at one time
    - Can be sent before an acknowledgment
    - Modified by the destination at any time depending on the buffer availability
24. What does network congestion result in? **(2) (S26)**
  - It results in packets being discarded
25. Comparison of TCP and UDP

| TCP                                                                       | UDP                                                                    |
| ------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Connection orientated                                                    | Connectionless                                                        |
| Stateful protocol                                                        | Stateless protocol                                                    |
| Reliable protocol, ensuring that all data arrive at the same destination | Non-reliable protocol Reliability must be handled by the application |
| More overhead                                                            | Low overhead                                                          |
| Acknowledgments data                                                     | Does not require acknowledgement                                      |
| Resends lost data                                                        | Does not resend lost data                                             |
| Delivers data in sequenced order                                         | Delivers data as it arrives                                           |
| Tracks transmitted data segments                                         | Fast                                                                  |
| Better for databases, web browsers, email clients                        | Better for live audio or video streaming, VoIP                        |
